byline.contributor: Julie Bosman reported from Chicago, and Richard Pérez-Peña, Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jad Mouawad from New York. Reporting was contributed by Ian Lovett from Los Angeles; Julie Hirschfeld Davis from Washington; and Nate Schweber, John Surico and Emily Palmer from New York.
byline.original: By JULIE BOSMAN, RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA, EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS and JAD MOUAWAD

abstract: Millions of Americans traveling for Thanksgiving week seem little deterred by State Department worldwide travel alert, warning travelers of terrorism threat; travelers at airports nationwide says they feel risk of terrorist attack is remote and are going about their lives with relative calm.
lead_paragraph: Americans are likely to see longer security lines and more careful screening during the holiday period. But airlines expect to carry more passengers than they have since 2007.

headline.main: Travel Alert or No, Many in U.S. Are Determined to Go Places for Thanksgiving
headline.print_headline: Amid Alerts and Worries, Thanksgiving Still Beckons

snippet: Americans are likely to see longer security lines and more careful screening during the holiday period. But airlines expect to carry more passengers than they have since 2007.
